title: Quebec City Day Trips
text:
If you're visiting Quebec City - one of Canada's great cities - consider exploring some of the Quebec region outside city borders. You'll find beautiful parks, charming towns, agricultural destinations and more. Île d'Orléans, Quebec. Photo © "St-Pierre-Ile-Orleans QC 2" by P199 . Licensed under CC BY-SA 3.0 via Wikimedia Commons 1. Île d'Orléans 
If you look 5 km (3.1 miles) east across the Saint Lawrence River from Quebec City, you will see the tip of Île d'Orléans. Though it looks unassuming, especially given the grandness of Old Quebec, it is a glorious haven of fresh agriculture, crafts, baked goods and the best chocolate dip soft ice cream I've ever had the pleasure to devour. 
The entire island is a designated historical district and was in fact where many of the first French settlers arrived. 
Visit the island for its food, scenery, heritage and handiwork. It provides a lovely rural complement to the urban bustle of Quebec City. 
The easiest way to get to Île d'Orléans is by public transportation or book a tour through your hotel concierge. More » Tadoussac is particularly famous as a whale watching destination. Photo © Hotel Tadoussac 2. Whale Watching 
Two and a half to three hours away from Quebec City is some of the whale watching in Canada . Book through your hotel concierge, Croisieres AML cruises, or book a day-long excursion online with Viator , which includes transportation. 
The two most viable locations to go whale watching from Quebec are Baie-Saint-Catherine and Tadoussac, which is slightly farther away and includes a ferry ride. On busy days, the lineup to get your car on the ferry can be quite long, so for a day trip, Baie-Sainte-Catherine is the more convenient choice, although there is not a lot else to do or many places to eat here. More » Jacques Cartier National Park, 30 minutes away from Quebec City, is a stunning landscape of mountainous plateau fractured by steep-sided valleys. Photo © Sepaq 3. Jacques Cartier National Park 
If you would like to escape into the Quebec wilderness, Jacques Cartier National Park is a half hour away. 
The park is open year-round and offers a range of activities, including snowshoeing, cross-country skiing, hiking, rafting and much more. Campsites, yurts and cabins are available overnight. 
Jacques Cartier Park staff and the website are excellent resources for planning your trip, be it by renting the equipment or finding what activity will best suit you or your group. 
When we visited the park, we rented inner tubes and floated down the Jacques Cartier River - a beautiful way to take in the valley scenery, especially with young kids, on a hot summer day. More » Sainte-Anne-de-Beaupré is a town near Quebec City famous for its cathedral. Photo - Yves Marcoux / Getty Images 
The riverside town of Beaupré is most famous for its double-spired Basilica of Sainte-Anne-de-Beaupré , which attracts thousands of pilgrims each year. Guided tours, masses and concerts are regularly open to the public. 
Beaupré is a straightforward 30 minute drive east of Quebec along the Saint Lawrence River. 
Combine a trip to Sainte Anne de Beaupré with a visit to Montmorency Falls: Book this trip with Viator . More » Wendake, Quebec, is home to a Huron-Wendat First Nation community and reserve. Photo © Tourism Wendake 5. Wendake 
Wendake, a town about 15 minutes north of Quebec City, offers a compelling glimpse into the heritage of the Huron-Wendat First Nation people that live here. Wendake is also home to the unique Hotel Musee Premieres Nations; an authentic long house; a 4-star boutique hotel inspired by long house architecture; and restaurant La Traite, which showcases indigenous Canadian cuisine. More » Mont-Sainte-Anne is an excellent family ski destination in a beautiful location. Photo © Chateau Mont-Sainte-Anne 
Mont-Saint-Anne in Beaupré - half an hour from Quebec City - is most famous as a ski destination but welcomes visitors year-round for its range of outdoor activities like hiking, mountain biking and central location for exploring the region. More » Stomach churning as we wait at the top of Everest. Photo © Jane McLean 7. Valcartier Village Vacances 
Valcartier Village Vacances , 20 minutes north of Quebec City, is acres and acres of unadulterated slip sliding fun in winter as a snow park and in summer as a water park. 
The park has been operating since 1963, when it opened with just a couple of slides. Today, the park is a year-round, multi-million operation. 
Read in detail about Valcartier Winter Playground . More » Montmorency Falls, just outside of Quebec City, is even higher than Niagara Falls . Photo © Jane McLean 8. Montmorency Falls 
Montmorency Falls is just a few kilometers away from Quebec City and makes a convenient stop en route to other locations, such as Beaupré or Île d'Orléans. 
You can take in the spectacle by taking a cable car ride or just by strolling out to the suspension bridge that provides wonderful views of the falls. A restaurant and shop are quite nice and provide additional views. 
The Falls are accessible year-round but do check the website on the day you want to go to ensure poor weather has not shut any of the facilities down. 
In winter Montmorency Falls is popular with ice climbers. More »
